    Recent Structural Advances of β1 and β2 Adrenoceptors Yield Keys for Ligand Recognition and Drug Design

    • Marvin A. Soriano-Ursúa*†
      • , 
    • José G. Trujillo-Ferrara†
      • , 
    • José Correa-Basurto†
      • , and 
    • Santiago Vilar‡
    View Author Information
    † Departments of Biochemistry and Physiology, Laboratory of Molecular Modeling and Bioinformatics, Postgraduate Research Section, Escuela Superior de Medicina, Instituto Politécnico Nacional, Plan de San Luis y Dı́az Mirón s/n, Mexico City, 11340, Mexico
    ‡ Department of Organic Chemistry, Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Santiago de Compostela, Santiago de Compostela, 15782, Spain
    *Phone: +52-55-57296000, extension 62747. Fax: +52-55-57296000, extension 62745. E-mail: [email protected]
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2013, 56, 21, 8207–8223
    Publication Date (Web):July 17, 2013

    SUBJECTS:

    • Receptors
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Because they represent attractive drug targets, adrenoceptors have been widely studied. Recent progress in structural data of β-adrenoceptors allows us to understand and predict key interactions in ligand recognition and receptor activation. Nevertheless, an important aspect of this process has only begun to be explored: the stabilization of a conformational state of these receptors upon contact with a ligand and the capacity of a ligand to influence receptor conformation through allosteric modulation, biased signaling, and selectivity. The aim of the present Perspective is to identify the well-defined orthosteric binding site and possible allosteric sites and to analyze the importance of the ligand–receptor interaction in the stabilization of certain receptor conformations. For this purpose, we have reviewed recent advances made through the use of X-ray data from ligand−β-adrenoceptor (including ADRB1 and ADRB2) crystal structures. Most importantly, implications in the medicinal chemistry field are explored in relation to drug design.

     Accession Codes

    PDB codes indicated in the manuscript are 2YCW, 2RH1, 4AMJ, and 3P0G.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Seven-transmembrane domain receptors (7TMRs) mediate biological responses of neurotransmitters and hormones, such as catecholamines 1 (dopamine; the identification for ligands is in bold Arabic numbers throughout the manuscript, as they appear in Figures 1 and 2), 2 (noradrenaline), and 3 (adrenaline). These amines have been intensely studied because catecholamine derivatives are considered attractive drugs for modulating functions of the cardiovascular, pulmonary, metabolic, and central nervous systems in humans.(1-3)
    Studies of catecholamine receptors have spearheaded several advances in pharmacological research. For instance, one of the first biomolecules whose study led to the acceptance of the receptor theory was 3.(4) Catecholamine adrenoceptors (ADRA1A, ADRA1B, ADRA1D, ADRA2A, ADRA2B, ADRA2C, ADRB1, ADRB2, and ADRB3 according IUPHAR classification) were among the first classified according to the preference of their endogenous ligands,(4) and adrenoceptors were among the first cloned membrane proteins.(4, 5) Not surprisingly, a wealth of X-ray structural data about catecholamine receptors, specifically ADRB1 and ADRB2, have been obtained in only a few years since the crystallization of the first transmembrane receptor protein.(6-15)
    Computational procedures carried out with recent structural data, especially from catecholamine receptors,(1, 16, 17) have provided new information on ligand recognition and receptor activation and thus are helping to predict key interactions in protein–ligand affinity. A new concept is coming to the fore from these theoretical studies: the importance of the ligand–receptor interaction in the stabilization of certain receptor conformations.
    Hence, the present focus is on the phenomena that lead to the stabilization of certain receptor conformations as a ligand follows its pathway to reach the orthosteric binding site (the active site reached by endogenous ligands). For this purpose, we review recent advances that have been made by employing X-ray data from ligand of β1–2-adrenoceptors (ADRBs) crystal structures in theoretical simulations and structure-based drug design. Overall, the analysis of these interactions is aimed at the identification of well-defined orthosteric and possible allosteric binding sites, the selectivity of ligands for binding to these sites, and the functional selectivity involved in the contact of a ligand with a receptor. Most importantly, implications in the medicinal chemistry field are explored.

    Recent Advances in X-ray Structural Data for ADRBs

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In only a few years since the first 7TMR X-ray crystal structure was obtained for a rhodopsin receptor,(6) the quantity of structural data about other 7TMRs has been rapidly increasing. Crystal data have become available for ADRB1s,(9, 15) ADRB2s,(7, 8, 10, 12-14) and other 7TMRs.(18) Consequently, crystal data are now available for the adenosine A2a receptor, dopamine D3 receptor, chemokine CX receptor, histamine H1 receptor, sphingosine S1PR 1-phosphate receptor 1, acetylcholine m2 and m3 receptors, opioid μ, κ, and δ receptors, FQ nociceptor, protease-activated receptor, 5-hydroxytryptamine receptors (5-HT1B, 5-HT2B), and SMO smoothened receptor, here ordered by their date of definition.(19-25)
    In the year 2000 rhodopsin was the first 7TMR to be crystallized.(6) In 2007 the first data for catecholamine receptors were obtained from X-ray crystal structures of ADRB2s, stabilized by an antibody interaction at the intracellular face or by the T4-lysozyme replacement of intracellular loop (ICL) 3 (Figure 3).(7, 8) These findings, along with many other structural details about ligand recognition, suggest that (a) compounds structurally related to catecholamines have a common or very similar binding site, as evidenced by the high sequence homology in binding sites among 7TMRs (and specifically between two ADRB2 structures), (b) the active and inactive conformational states of a receptor are not necessarily dependent on the conformations of the “ionic lock” recently described between Asp130(3.49) (according to Ballesteros–Weinstein numbering in superscript numbers) and Glu268(6.30) in the cytoplasmic region of rhodopsin, and (c) new X-ray crystal structures can be obtained after the stabilization of unstable intracellular domains.(1)
    In 2008 a new experimental strategy for obtaining crystal structures revealed the structure of ADRB1s. Through punctual “thermostabilizing” mutations,(9) the crystal was obtained with an antagonist, and once again the ionic lock was seen to be broken. This ADRB1 structure shows great similarity with ADRB2s in the transmembrane domains, with some important differences in the organization of intraextracellular loops. On the basis of this structural data, it was proposed that the second extracellular loop defines the entrance of the ligand to the binding pocket. In addition, docking simulations with agonists provided evidence that the binding pocket closes when a ligand arrives to this site, which could be influenced by the second extracellular loop (Figure 3).(9)
    In contrast to the sequence and conformational similarity of the extracellular loops and transmembrane domains of human ADRB1s and ADRB2s, there are pronounced differences in the intracellular loops. For example, the third intracellular loop of ADRB1s, but not ADRB2s, has a 24-amino acid sequence containing 14 prolines. Deletion of the proline-rich region of ADRB1s improves the potency of 4 (isoproterenol) for activating adenylyl cyclase, while insertion of this sequence into ADRB2s reduces potency.(26) Previously it was calculated, based on results from human ventricular myocardium, that a ADRB2–catecholamine complex leads to the production of 4-fold more cAMP molecules than a ADRB1–catecholamine complex(27) and that the efficacy for stimulating adenylyl cyclase was greater for activated ADRB2s than ADRB1s.(28) Overall, these results are consistent with a tighter coupling of ADRB2s than ADRB1s to a Gs protein. A consequence of the selective Gs coupling is that activation of human myocardial ADRB2s and ADRB1s causes similar maximum cardiostimulation despite the 2- to 3-fold lower ADRB2 density.(29, 30)
    In 2010 the structure of the closely related dopamine D3 receptor was elucidated, in this case in complex with a D2/D3 selective antagonist. Details of the extracellular domains suggested a second binding pocket for a ligand in the extracellular region, leading to a new panorama of possibilities for selectivity in the interaction of ligands with dopamine D2/D3 receptors and other catecholamine receptors.(11) Since then, both ADRB1s and ADRB2s have been crystallized in complex with several ligands that have different intrinsic activity on G-protein-dependent signaling. Such ligands include inverse agonists, partial and full agonists, neutral antagonists, and nanobodies that modify the intrinsic activity of these receptors.(8, 10, 12, 13) Moreover, a ADRB2 was recently crystallized in complex with the G-protein that is commonly found in mammalian cells,(14) and X-ray crystal structures have been obtained for a ADRB1 in complex with “biased ligands”. The latter ligands behave as blockers of G-protein-dependent signaling and at the same time as agonists in G-protein-independent signaling.(15) Furthermore, ADRB1s have been crystallized in ligand-free oligomer complexes coupled with G-proteins (Figure 3).(31)
    These remarkable advances in relation to ADRB1 and ADRB2 structural biology afford new insights into the function of adrenoceptors and other 7TMRs. Research done with the crystal structures of adrenoceptors has focused on the capacity of diffusible ligands to reach the orthosteric binding site. In addition, some evidence has been reported that is in accordance with the existence of one or more allosteric binding regions.(32, 33) On the basis of this evidence, we will explore various possibilities (i) that one of a repertoire of conformations is stabilized as a ligand approaches these receptors, (ii) that the stabilization of this conformation is related to allosteric modulation, and (iii) that this stabilized conformation in turn influences the capacity of the ligand to adhere to one or more binding regions in the known orthosteric binding site.(34-36)

    Essential Role of Extracellular Loops in Ligand Binding and Adrenoceptor Activation

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    After analysis of the X-ray crystal structure of various 7TMRs belonging the rhodopsin family and the differences between these receptors in their seven domains, the role of extracellular loops has been constantly linked to selectivity and to the existence of allosteric binding regions.(37-39) Independent of the strategy for crystallization or the ligand–receptor complex from which the crystal was obtained, it has been observed that extracellular loops afford conformational stability as well as structural diversity in 7TMRs. They even show low sequence homology within subfamilies.(39) It is this very diversity in structure that could explain experimentally observed differences in selectivity and other phenomena during the ligand binding process.(40)
    In the past few years, new insights have been made into the role of the extracellular loops in receptor activation and ligand binding.(39) As an example, some mutations in 7TMRs located in the extracellular loops are now known to be responsible for different human diseases.(39, 41) This is consistent with the idea that these loops participate in the final effect of the signaling cascade. In order to understand the role of extracellular loops, we look at the residues in a region recently named “the ligand binding module”, which includes extracellular loops as well as the segments of transmembrane domains that are closest to the extracellular environment (Figure 4).(40)
    Although the first extracellular loop (ECL1) does not seem to be directly involved in ligand binding, different reports emphasize the influence of this loop in the conformation of the orthosteric binding site of different 7TMRs.(38, 42, 43) For example, it has been described that some residues in ECL1, such as Asp105 of the NPS receptor,(42) as well as residues at positions 71 and 74 of the adenosine A2B receptors, could be important for receptor signaling. The importance of ECL1 function is also suggested by results from mutagenesis studies in the neurotensin NTS1 receptor,(44) the complement component receptor 5a receptor-1,(45) as well as vasopressin receptors(46) and acetylcholine muscarinic receptors.(47) The same motif has been found in many rhodopsin-like 7TMRs. Further studies are needed to shed more light on the function of ECL1 in ADRB1s and ADRB2s.(39, 45)
    According to recent evidence, the second extracellular loop (ECL2) is more important than ECL1 in orthosteric and allosteric ligand binding, as well as in ADRB’s signaling (Figure 4). Some residues in ECL2 could be involved in the orthosteric binding site, as suggested by ADRB1 and ADRB2 crystal structures.(8, 9) Additionally, it has been proposed that ECL2 is involved in the binding of antagonists to the ADRA1A.(48)
    Apart from this direct role in ligand binding, ECL2 may also be involved in the signaling triggered by adrenoceptor allosteric binding sites, which could in turn influence binding to orthosteric sites.(39) A role of ECL2 in allosteric modulation has been suggested in different 7TMRs, such as muscarinic receptors.(38) Some studies with antibodies aimed at ECL2 of ADRB1s and ADRB2s have shown allosteric modulation that importantly influences the effect of signaling.(49) Antibodies against the ECL2 of ADRB1s generate an agonist-like effect and cause idiopathic cardiomyopathy.(50, 51) An agonistic effect of antibodies has also been reported for porcine ADRB2s but with limited information.(52) Finally, there is a report from a study employing molecular dynamics (MD) simulations with a ADRB2 that ECL2 can participate actively in the ligand entry process, pointing to possible metastable binding sites for allosteric modulation.(53) The authors hypothesized that some ADRB2 ligands first became involved with the extracellular region enclosed by ECL2, ECL3, and helices 5–7 before moving into the binding pocket.(53)
    Various reports have provided additional evidence involving ECL2 in allosteric modulation of adrenoceptors. Some studies show that making ECL2 more rigid could drastically affect ADRB2 function, indicating that certain flexibility in ECL2 is necessary for the efficient activation of the receptor.(37, 54) Bokoch et al.(37) showed that the salt bridge in ADRB2s between Lys305(7.32) and Asp192(EL2.51) was weakened in the active conformation of the receptor. Through NMR spectroscopy, the authors found that agonists, neutral antagonists, and inverse agonists induced the stability of different conformations in the extracellular domain.(37) In agreement with these results, computational studies using MD simulations have indicated a role of ECL2 in receptor activation.(54) An analysis of binding modes of agonists and blockers in ADRB2s has suggested that freedom of motion of ECL2 is required for displacement of the TM5 domain and the activation of the receptor.(54)
    Similar results indicating the importance of ECL2 have been reported for other 7TMRs.(55-63) TM helix movement has been found to be coupled to the displacement of ECL2 during the activation of rhodopsin.(62) This loop is apparently involved in the regulation of ligand activity in dopamine D2 receptors as well.(61) On the basis of MD simulations in the P2Y6 receptor, it has been proposed that agonist binding interrupts the formation of a salt bridge between the TM3 and ECL2 domains.(57) Avlani et al.(64) studied the M2 muscarinic acetylcholine receptor, reporting a connection between a reduction in ECL2 flexibility and a significant inhibition of the binding of orthosteric ligands and allosteric modulators. Overall, it appears that ECL2 is the loop with the greatest influence on receptor activation.
    ECL3 has also been reported to influence the activation of some adrenoceptors, although it apparently plays a less essential role than ECL2. In a recent study, Zhao et al.(65) substituted ECL3 in a ADRB2 with the corresponding residues in the α1a-adrenoceptor. Although no changes were detected in antagonist activity, the results showed an increase in the potency of some agonists and a higher basal activity of adenylyl cyclase catalytic activity. There is also evidence that ECL3 may participate in the entrance of ligands to ADRB2s.(53)
    Other studies with 7TMRs confirm the importance of ECL3 in receptor signaling.(38, 66) Claus et al.(67) located a hydrophobic cluster in ECL3 that is important in thyrotropin activation. Similarly, a hydrophobic cluster in ECL3 of the opioid δ receptor could trigger an activation pathway, evidenced by observations from random mutagenesis and three-dimensional modeling.(68) There are many reports indicating that ECL3 can interact with other extracellular regions and influence allosteric and orthosteric binding in 7TMRs.(38, 47, 66, 69) Furthermore, ECL3 can exert a direct influence when some of its residues are very close to the ligand binding site or form part of it.(70)
    Hence, recent reports have suggested the importance of extracellular loops in ligand binding to adrenoceptors and other receptors. Further research into conformational coupling between the extracellular surface and the orthosteric binding site in the adrenoceptors could further rationalize the design of new drugs as allosteric or dualsteric modulators by targeting the extracellular surface.

    Background on Allosterism in Relation to ADRBs

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Spontaneous changes occur in receptors as they pass through their repertoire of conformations. It is accepted that biological activity is a function of the population of receptors stabilized in a certain conformational state. When a ligand binds to the orthosteric site, a conformational state is induced. Depending on whether the ligand is an agonist or antagonist, this conformational state either activates or inactivates the receptor or maintains it at basal activity. In the case of an agonist, including partial agonists (e.g., 27 (CGP12177) and 29 (pindolol)) or inverse agonists (e.g., 30 (ICI118,551)), the conformational state induced alters the basal kinetic activity of a receptor or a system coupled to this receptor. Contrarily, neutral antagonists, which for adrenoceptors are rare, block the binding of agonists.
    A ligand can also stabilize a conformational state by binding to an allosteric region (a region other than that included in the cluster of residues forming the pocket of the active binding site reached by endogenous ligands). Although such a ligand, known as an allosteric modulator,(71) hardly affects kinetic processes, it can greatly influence ligand–receptor interactions in several ways, including the capacity of ligands to access the orthosteric site. There is increasing interest in this relatively new field of allosteric modulation of 7TMRs,(70-74) essentially due the promise of improved selectivity and tolerability of ligands that target these receptors.(70, 74-78)
    As a result of relatively recent insights, new nomenclature for ligands has come about that goes beyond the general terms of agonists, antagonists, and allosteric modulators. The new terms include dualsteric–bitopic ligands (which make contact with the orthosteric site and allosteric regions in a concerted way), agoallosteric ligands (which exert agonistic activity by binding to an allosteric region and may modulate the affinity and/or efficacy of a ligand at the orthosteric site), and superagonists (exogenous compounds that induce receptor activation with higher efficacy than endogenous ligands).(79)
    Despite the increasing evidence of allosteric modulation on ADRBs, the only allosteric modulator of βARs confirmed by experimental evidence is zinc. Even with this ligand, the coordinates of its allosteric site are poorly defined.(80) However, the capacity of zinc to affect the release of neurotransmitters at nerve endings and consequently modulate signaling by the ADRB2 in vivo has pointed to the need for more in-depth studies of the allosteric phenomena.(80) The suggestion that other ligands are allosteric modulators results from effects observed on ADRB1 and ADRB2 signaling.(35) The probabilities of allosteric modulation of 7TMRs are multiplied when ADRBs are found in oligomeric forms.(31, 81) Differences in ligand affinity have been observed in vitro between 7TMRs, monomers of ADRB2s, and homo- and hetero-oligomers of ADRB2s.(81, 82) Recent advances in the structural biology of 7TMRs, such as the 2-fold symmetrical dimer of crystallized μ receptors or the recent ligand-free oligomers of ADRB1s, could greatly facilitate the study of allosteric modulation.(18, 31)
    Hence, it is becoming increasingly clear that a certain conformational state can be stabilized by the binding of a ligand to an allosteric site. Further insights into this aspect of receptor activation will afford ever greater possibilities for drug design and efficacy.

    Data about the Existence of More than One Binding Site and/or Notably Distinct Conformational States with ADRBs

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Detailed observation of ligand interactions on ADRB1s, and in some cases on ADRB2s, has provided experimental evidence of two different agonist affinity values in binding assays. This has led to the hypothesis of two binding sites and/or two or more conformational states involved in these interactions.(32, 83-86) Evidence exists to support the idea that these sites or conformational states can influence not only the intrinsic activity of a ligand but also the duration of its effect.(32, 87-90)
    A few different types of experimental data support the hypothesis that ligand binding induces a certain conformational state of a receptor. Examples include the use of radiolabeled ligands (e.g., 3H-CGP12177) in binding assays(84) and fluorescent or bioluminescent resonance energy transfer.(37, 90) In order to explore this hypothesis, theoretical studies with rigid crystals or refined 7TMR structures have been carried out.(32) Some of these computational studies support the existence of distinct 7TMR conformational states, which could be related to the variations in signaling found experimentally.(50, 91-94) It is accepted that there is a wide variety of ligand-binding modes on 7TMRs and that each has a different degree of interaction with regions involved in known conformational states and related triggers.(70) Thus, it is important to generate adequate models from X-ray crystal structures of 7TMRs that can take ligand-induced conformational states into account.(94, 95)
    In relation to ADRB1s, experimental ligand saturation analysis supports the existence of two distinct binding sites(84, 96, 97) for several ligands with agonist properties,(84, 97-99) including catecholamines.(98) If in fact there are two binding sites, each one must necessarily be associated with different binding partners (residues) within the receptor protein.(100) Even different ligands are apparently recognized by distinct amino acid residues in the same binding crevice (which could have a great surface area),(101) as evidenced by some docking simulations on ADRB2 structures.(32, 100)
    Although the precise coordinates of a secondary binding site is an unresolved topic, site-directed mutagenesis studies suggest that residues in TM3 to TM7 and ECL2 may be involved in a secondary region included in or near the orthosteric binding site on structures of ADRBs. Some of these studies have mapped the proposed residues.(32, 35, 102-106)
    Take for instance Asp121(3.32), a crucial residue that is always found to be present in the orthosteric binding site and that participates in the catecholamine recognition at the high-affinity site. Even though it is not directly involved in the interaction between the partial antagonist 27 and the ADRB1 low-affinity site, its mutation generated effects at this site, which suggests a role in allosteric modulation.(107) Additionally, inferences from the structure–activity relationship of ligands with ADRB1s suggest that residues in the TM5 domain could be involved in the function of the proposed low-affinity site.(84) When known ADRB1 ligands were added to the complexes of ADRB1 antibodies (against residues 197–222), there was an increase in the potency and efficacy of the latter at the high-affinity site, without disrupting the ligand binding on the low-affinity site(51) (as evidenced by the fact that the data for the low affinity site were unchanged). This suggests that these ADRB1 ligands bound at the same high-affinity site as that occupied by the antibodies or to another closely related site.
    Although the binding of a ligand to an allosteric region would probably generate a different conformational state, it is yet unknown what effect this could have on ligand binding to the orthosteric site or receptor efficacy. One important question that arises in this regard is whether this conformational change induces the second extracellular loop to move away from the orthosteric site, therefore leaving it more available for ligand binding, or allows this loop to have a more direct role in receptor activation by perhaps pushing the ligand toward the orthosteric site.
    The first molecular modeling studies that gave evidence of a possible secondary binding region on ADRB2s(32, 96) suggest that such a region is deeper than the known orthosteric site.(108, 109) According to our recent studies using theoretical calculation programs that generate binding site maps, the pocket of the proposed secondary binding region seems to be shallower than and very close to that of the orthosteric site. We and other researchers have found not only a subset of amino acids for specific recognition of ligands but also the theoretical evidence for the anchoring of a ligand to this region on ADRB2s.(32, 89, 110) Interestingly, docking simulations indicate that the secondary binding region is present in the conformational state that shows the highest ligand–ADRB2 affinity values. The proposed secondary binding region essentially consists of residues in the TM2, TM3, TM6, and TM7 domains, with a contribution from two residues (Asp192(EL2.51) and Phe193(EL2.52)) in the second extracellular loop.(32)
    It is possible to consider that a single wide binding site exists with different functional areas, assuming that the orthosteric binding site is the only one recognized by an endogenous ligand. However, we propose that the orthosteric site is not in fact the only binding site in the adrenoceptor pocket and that a second binding region in the same crevice could be responsible for activating a different signaling pathway. Studies with 18 (fenoterol) derivatives have indeed provided evidence of the latter proposal.(110) The existence of a secondary region in the same pocket as the orthosteric binding site has also been suggested by González et al.,(88) based on results from steered MD simulations in which the ligand anchors itself at an alternative region. According to their results, this possible secondary region is sandwiched between ECL2 and the TM7 domain, a slightly shallower region than that found in our studies.(32) They suggest that this secondary region is probably involved in determining which of two possible pathways a ligand follows to approach the orthosteric site.(32, 88)
    Other recent simulations using MD report a pathway and mechanism for drug binding that are congruent with the possibility of a secondary region located in or near pocket of the orthosteric site.(52, 73) Recent reports using the X-ray crystal structures of some ADRB2–ligand complexes (with 12 (IB167107), 15 (FAUC50)) show that an arylethyl moiety of a dimeric arylethylamine compound linked by a central amine group is also exposed to a region shallower than the well-known orthosteric site on some non-adrenoceptor 7TMRs (e.g., ZM241385 on adenosine A2a receptor, JDTic on the opioid κ receptor, and naltrindole on the opioid δ receptor).(18) This suggests that this secondary region in ADRBs is probably important for modulation of selectivity by ligands acting on other 7TMRs.(38, 39)

    Dualsteric-Anchoring on ADRB1 and ADRB2: Its Relationship with Biased Signaling

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Another aspect of the plastic and multistate characteristic of 7TMRs is so-called biased signaling by ligands of these receptors, meaning that some ligands have a preference (bias) for one of two signaling pathways: the G-protein-dependent pathway or the β-arrestin pathway. The latter pathway is closely related to the extracellular regulated kinase (ERK) dependent signaling. In addition to “biased signaling”, this characteristic of ligands has been denominated “ligand-directed stimulus trafficking”, “functional selectivity”, and “biased agonism”.(111-117) Several research groups, focusing on the manner in which biased action is regulated, have shed light on this matter.(111-113) According to their results, G-protein-dependent signaling is activated by the orthosteric site, and β-arrestin signaling involves a specific interaction at a secondary allosteric region (see below).(32) A secondary binding region and a β-arrestin signaling pathway (e.g., the ERK1/2, ERK pathway), explored in recent years for βARs as well as for other 7TMRs, could account for some as yet unexplained phenomenon evidenced by theoretical calculations and experimental data. For example, carvedilol and bucindolol (biased agonists) block G-protein signaling but also induce desensitization and internalization of receptors that activate the β-arrestin pathway. That is, they are antagonists on the adenylyl cyclase pathway but agonists on the β-arrestin pathway. Recently obtained X-ray crystal structural data from complexes of ADRB1s show that these effects could possibly be caused by the binding of moieties of these ligands to an allosteric binding region. Indeed, there is a report suggesting that these ligands bind to a region shallower than the orthosteric binding site and in so doing lead to G-protein-independent β-arrestin activation.(15, 112)
    On the other hand, there are compounds that have concerted contact with both sites on crystal structures of ADRBs and therefore can activate both these pathways simultaneously.(15, 112) An example of this effect, known as unbiased signaling, is provided by 13 (dobutamine). Through the Gs protein pathway, it induces 100% of the signaling found with 4. Through the β-arrestin pathway, it induces 70% of such signaling. It turns out that 13 exposes a moiety, which is structurally related to 24 (carvedilol) and 25 (bucindolol), to the same shallower region that is activated by these drugs.(118) Overall, this evidence suggests the existence of a secondary binding region related to β-arrestin signaling, which is located in a pocket on ADRB1s between the TM3, TM6, and TM7 domains.(15, 118)
    The detailed functionality of this region is only beginning to be studied. For instance, it has been observed that moieties appended to the hydroxylamine “tail” of the ligands that contact this secondary binding site induce a conformational change, which in turn activates the β-arrestin pathway. Among such moieties, it has been suggested that large nonpolar groups are particularly effective in the activation of this pathway.(112) Recent research about interaction between arrestins and other 7TMRs support the involvement of these transmembrane domains in the activation of the β-arrestin pathway.(119-122)
    Similar evidence has been found in relation to partial/full agonists that induce biased signaling with ADRB2s. Recent assays that rearranged the TM7 domain of ADRB2s, labeled with fluorine-19 and monitored by nuclear magnetic resonance, suggest that the alteration of this residue has a profound effect on the activation of the β-arrestin pathway.(34) Additionally, ADRB2s that have been crystallized with a ligand in the orthosteric binding site show that this ligand exposes an arylethylamine moiety to a region shallower than the orthosteric binding site (12 and 15), which presumably modifies the TM7 domain. It is becoming apparent that these compounds behave as long-term full agonists on the Gs-protein dependent pathway, without any apparent activation of the β-arrestin pathway, which means that they are biased ligands.(12, 13)

    Profile of the β-Arrestin Signaling Pathway

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As a first step in developing a profile of signaling through the β-arrestin pathway, one research group proposed a relationship between the chemical structure of a ligand, taking into account a panel of ADRB1 and ADRB2 ligands, and the efficacy of activation of a particular signaling pathway.(123, 124) In this effort, the researchers built a Cartesian representation of the ligand profiles on ADRB1s and ADRB2s, based on the possible activation of one of two signaling pathways. Their bidimensional representation included four possible efficacy quadrants,(124) suggesting that by interacting with particular residues, certain ligand moieties induce a conformational state favoring either the Gs-protein or β-arrestin signaling pathway.
    We used this Cartesian model to represent an even more specific relationship: between structural moieties of ADRB1 or ADRB2 ligands and activation of the adenylyl cyclase (AC) or β-arrestin (ERK1/2) signaling pathway (Figure 5). We found that ligands require a 4-phenolethanolamine moiety for AC activation (Figures 1, 2, and 5, in red). Furthermore, the presence of an additional hydroxyl group in position 3 of the aromatic ring is necessary for a compound to act as a full agonist (Figures 1, 2, and 5, in green). The moiety with hydroxyl substitutions in positions 3 and 4 appears to be responsible for the capability of ligands to trigger full signaling through the AC pathway. This moiety seems to establish more interactions with serines in the TM5 domain and to make contact with Ser(5.46), thus generating a new conformational rearrangement of the receptor. Supporting this conclusion, theoretical and experimental studies on X-ray crystal structures of ADRB1s and ADRB2s in complex with various compounds have shown that full agonists, but not partial agonists, make contact with Ser(5.46)i n order to act through the AC pathway.(10, 125, 126) On the other hand, it can be observed that the oxypropylamine moiety (Figures 1, 2, and 5, in gray) confers ligands with the capability of inducing neutral antagonism or inverse agonism through the Gs-dependent AC pathway.
    Interestingly, on the other side of the amine moiety of these same “catecholamine-like” root compounds, there can be a variety of other moieties (also arylethyl moieties). It seems that the β-arrestin pathway (Figures 1, 2, and 5, in blue) is induced by one of these arylethyl moieties, while the AC pathway is induced by another almost equivalent fragment group (Figures 1, 2, and 5, in red). That is, one arylethyl moiety appears to bind to the orthosteric binding site, and the other binds to the nearby shallower region. When a ligand contacts this secondary binding region, the moiety of the α-carbon to amine and/or that in the ortho/para position on the aromatic ring of the arylethylamine (Figures 1, 2, and 5, in magenta) are probably important for inducing activity through the β-arrestin pathway.
    On the basis of the aforementioned evidence and results from biophysics studies,(32, 53) our group proposes that this shallower secondary binding region can be anchored by ligands only when an adequate conformational state allows it to be exposed. Furthermore, it is possible that upon their approach to a receptor, specific moieties in a ligand induce such a conformation by making the adequate arrangements between the TM3 and TM6 domains.(32)
    It can be observed in Figures 1 and 2 that simpler molecules seem to be unbiased ligands, able to activate the adenylyl cyclase or the β-arrestin pathways.(127, 128) These simpler molecules have a small moiety attached to the amine group, like the endogenous ligands 2 and 3. Also, exogenous ligands 4, 25, and 28 (propranolol) share an isopropyl moiety linked to the amino group, and all three have high activity at the β-arrestin pathway, even though they are full, partial, and inverse agonists for the AC-pathway, respectively. Molecules with an even bulkier moiety attached to the amine group, including 5 (albuterol), 8 (clenbuterol), and 11 (terbutaline) (sharing a terbutyl moiety), act as agonists for cAMP production while displaying an even weaker effect on the β-arrestin-mediated phosphorylation pathway.(128) In these cases, it seems that steric hindrance blocks the activation of the β-arrestin pathway. Additional studies should be carried out to identify adjacent moieties in ligands and the extent of the binding site reached because other compounds, such as 16 (procaterol) and 19 (cimaterol) (with only a isopropyl moiety linked to the amine region but unflexible moieties in catechol-related group), show a weak effect on the β-arrestin-pathway.(128)
    Finally, there are molecules with a long tail but without a bulky moiety attached contiguously to the amine group, such as 6 (salmeterol), 7 (formoterol), and 14 (carmoterol) (sharing two arylethyl moieties in their structure), which can fit into the orthosteric binding site and secondary shallower region in a concerted way. Thus, the concerted binding to both the orthosteric binding site and a secondary region seems to take place in one of two ways: by a nonbulky long-tailed molecule or by two small molecules (including endogenous ligands). It appears that small molecules do indeed bind to two nearby surfaces on both ADRB1 and ADRB2s, which may occur almost simultaneously. The structural data of ligands that seem to act in this way are very similar (Table 1). However, further studies, such as equivalence analyses, are necessary to confirm this hypothesis.
    Table 1. Amino Acids Involved in the Binding Site for ADRBs
    Table a

    From Warne et al.(15) for ADRB1 and from Rosenbaum et al.(12) and Wacker et al.(10) for ADRB2. The amino acids are colored in agreement with the proposed interactions with moieties of ligands marked in Figure 3, related to functional selectivity. Amino acids represented in black are those whose contacts with ligands are only mentioned in one adrenoceptor sybtype (ADRB1 or ADRB2) according to the crystal structures.

    Implications of a Secondary Binding Region for the Duration of ADRB–Ligand Activity

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The contact of a ligand with a secondary region could affect not only the intrinsic activity or signaling pathways but also the duration of some ADRB2–ligand interactions. For instance, when 6, 7, and 14 concertedly reach a secondary region and the orthosteric binding site,(32, 129, 130) ligand binding with the secondary region could stabilize an active conformational state and thus reduce or prevent the phosphorylation process of the receptor that is associated with the regulation of its expression on the cell membrane. This possibility could be important for countering the down-regulation process that leads to the lack of responsiveness with chronic use of bronchodilator drugs.(113, 128, 131) Further research will reveal if this represents an effective new drug design strategy to yield ultralong acting ADRB2–ligands for treatment of patients with chronic pathologies requiring long-term therapy. Indeed, some recently developed compounds, including 9 (vilanterol), 14, and 20 (milveterol), have structures that likely reach the proposed secondary binding region.(129, 132, 133) Without a conscious strategy aimed at the development of compounds that could activate a secondary binding region, drugs were discovered that have high potency, a long lasting effect, and variable efficacy, apparently by concertedly activating the G-protein-dependent and -independent pathways.
    Recently, with the aim of generating new ADRB2 ligands, Jacobsen et al. studied the possibility of reaching the orthosteric binding site and a possible secondary exosite.(132) According to their results, the compounds with high potency and long duration have an arylethyl moiety linked to an amine group of a “noradrenaline” moiety. Contrarily, other compounds that have other moieties, such as aliphatic chains or nonaromatic rings linked to an amine moiety, showed weak binding affinity.(132) Alcaraz et al.(134) and Shan et al.(135) obtained ultralong lasting agonists with structurally similar compounds. Furthermore, Shan et al. suggested that the compounds with high efficacy also inhibit the enzymatic activity of phosphodiesterases, which would have a cAMP-mediated long-term relaxing effect on respiratory smooth muscle tissue.(135)
    The possibility that a secondary binding region is involved in biased signaling and the duration of action is an idea with broad implications for other 7TMRs. For instance, non-peptide ligands (e.g., JDTic on the opioid κ receptor, naltrindole on the opioid δ receptor, and the peptide encephalines) have an arylamine fragment from a tyrosine residue in the first position that seems to reach an allosteric binding site in a region homologous to that found on ADRB1s and ADRB2s when these receptors are activated at the orthosteric site (Figures 1 and 2). Indeed, it has been demonstrated that the substitution of tyrosine enhances the potency and long-lasting action of peptides on opioid receptors.(136, 137)

    Selectivity for ADRB1s or ADRB2s Is Also Related to a Shallower Region than the Orthosteric Site

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A major challenge in medicinal chemistry is to design a molecule that selectively binds to its target receptor and does not cause unintended side effects by binding to other similar receptors. Therefore, increasing efforts have been made to elucidate the key for designing compounds with this capability.(1, 138-140) In general, ADRBs are activated by compounds with a bulky moiety linked to an amine group. Other structural data for ligands have been suggested from experimental determinations of affinity values and modifications of cAMP levels in systems expressing ADRBs.(140, 141) In addition to identifying moieties that are key for adrenoceptor activation or inhibition, it is necessary to determine the specific residues involved in ligand recognition.(142, 143) Indeed, the importance of specific residues and adrenoceptor regions for ligand binding has been suggested by punctual mutation experiments and through the elucidation of crystal structures.(35) One finding has been the seemingly central role played by the second extracellular loop.(55, 144) In the transmembrane region, residues at 5.39 and 5.46 in the TM5 domain, at 6.55 in the TM6 domain, and at 7.35 in the TM7 domain have been mentioned as keys for selectivity on ADRB1s or ADRB2s (see Table 1 for the corresponding residues in human ADRB1 and ADRB2).(85, 145-147)
    Recent structural data from ADRB1s and ADRB2s have provided limited but important information about selectivity. Accordingly, Kobilka has suggested that selectivity for one of these receptor subtypes is determined by Phe325(7.35) for ADRB1s and Tyr308(7.35) for ADRB2s. He also suggested other residues, such as those in position 7.39, that could be key in the selectivity of ligands for other adrenoceptor subtypes.(1) Molecular modeling and MD simulations using these structures have yielded some data related with selectivity. These data are partly in agreement with the aforementioned experimental results. For example, on the basis of results of molecular modeling, Roy and Saxena proposed that residues in position 6.58 (Asn, His, and Arg for human ADRB1s, ADRB2s, and ADRB3s, respectively), position 7.35 (Phe or Tyr for human ADRBs), and position 7.43 (Tyr in the three human ADRB subtypes) could be involved in selectivity of ligands for ADRB1s or ADRB2s.(148)
    On the other hand, Selvam et al. proposed that differences exist in the pathways by which ligands enter and leave ADRB subtypes, based on results from MD simulations.(149) They showed different preferences between ADRB1s and ADRB2s in antagonist unbinding pathways. Specifically, with ADRB1s the pathway by which the ligand unbinds tends to be perpendicular to the membrane of the receptor, whereas with ADRB2s the pathway by which the ligand unbinds tends to be lateral to the membrane of the receptor. In the latter case, this unbinding involves domains TM5, TM6, and TM7. They also suggest that the residue at 6.58 is a determinant for turkey ADRB1 and a cluster of hydrophobic residues (His296(6.58), Tyr308(7.35), Phe193(EL2.52), and Phe194(EL2.53) in ECL2) for human ADRB2.(149) In this sense, another theoretical study carried out by Kaszuba et al. with 32 (nebivolol) showed that residues at positions 2.64, 6.58, 7.35, and 7.36 are related to receptor subtype selectivity.(150)
    Overall, this evidence suggests that selectivity for one or another ADRB subtype is due to a selective diffusion through a pathway to reach the orthosteric binding site. Although the identification of key residues is only the beginning in relation to this process, it is known that there is involvement of some of the residues constituting the secondary binding region that has been proposed.(32, 84, 150) Further studies are required to propose the design of ligands with specific moieties that favor one or another adrenoceptor subtype.

    Stereoselectivity on ADRBs Involve Interactions on Shallower Regions and the Orthosteric Binding Site

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A great deal of research is being done about the stereochemical preferences of the main pharmacological receptors.(150, 151) Stereochemical processes are essential in the synthesis of compounds, in ligand recognition and induced activation of signaling pathways, as well as in the metabolism of molecules targeting the ADRBs.(151-153)
    The importance of chiral carbons in ligands with ADRB agonist activity has been recognized for many years. In 1908 Cushny determined that the vasoconstriction produced on frogs by R-adrenaline was greater than that by S-adrenaline.(142) The recognition properties of each stereoisomer are currently being studied, finding that the affinity energy and signaling response are different. This could be the reason that some treatments fail when the molecules are administrated as a racemic mixture.
    One clear example of how the focus on stereochemistry has borne fruit is in relation to the ADRB2 agonist 5, which has an (R) or (S) configuration. These enantiomers probably exert different effects on airway relaxation and regulation of inflammation. Indeed, a drug representing a single enantiomer of 5 (levalbuterol) is currently available for patients.(142, 154) Some patterns have been observed for the structure–stereoselectivity relationship. For instance, a common feature in the primary structure of most of the arylamine ADRB ligands is the presence of a hydroxyl group in the β (to amine) carbon.(155) However, this feature is not essential, as evidenced by the fact that catechol and 1, which do not have a chiral carbon, successfully activate biased signaling pathways.(156, 157)
    Certain residues in ADRBs have been related to selectivity for one or another stereoisomer. In arylamines the role of this ligand moiety on binding kinetics, affinity, and agonist activity has been confirmed, and the location of some key residues has been determined. Through site-directed mutagenesis studies, Ser165(4.57) (related to orthosteric site), Asn293(6.55), and Tyr308(7.35) (both in the top or regions shallower than orthosteric site) have been described as key residues in ADRB2 stereoselectivity.(130, 151, 158) In silico approaches support the importance of Asn293(6.55) and Tyr308(7.35) in the stereoselectivity of ADRB2 (or their homologous residues in ADRB1).(35, 130, 159, 160) Moreover, the elucidation of adrenoceptor structures has yielded some data about stereoselectivity. For either R or S ligands, the interactions of hydroxyl group with residues at position 3.32 or 7.39 are selective for anchoring these stereoisomers. It is not clear whether interactions with some serines in TM5 or Asn in position 6.55 are determinant in the anchoring of a steroisomer of ligands to the orthosteric site.(35)
    In the recently discovered biarylamine compounds, a second chiral carbon is included, which is often located in position α to the amine. Rather than being a hydroxyl group, the moiety is usually a methyl group. Apparently, the role of this moiety is important to the efficacy of the β-arrestin pathway, suggested by the interactions of biased ligands with residues at position 7.43, a probable secondary “toggle switch” that induces relevant conformational changes for the TM6 and TM7 domains, which are clearly involved in this signaling pathway.(94, 148, 158, 161)
    The apparent selectivity of each of these chiral centers for different pathways (adenylyl cyclase vs β-arrestin) is in agreement with the thermodynamics study of the isomeric forms of 18 by Jozwiak et al.(159) Their data demonstrate that the chirality of the carbon atom containing the β-hydroxyl group of the 18 molecule (the β-OH carbon) is a key factor in determining whether the binding process is antagonist-enthalpy-driven (for S,S or S,R isomers) or agonist-entropy-driven (for R,R or R,S isomers) on the adenylyl cyclase pathway.(143) Kaszuba et al. (2010)(150) also found stereoselective affinity through molecular dynamics studies of 32, a ADRB blocker. This compound has a hydroxyl group in one of the two β to amine carbons, and different activities have been demonstrated for its isomers.(150) Furthermore, the residues involved can have an indirect effect by moving water molecules around the ligand during the binding process. As can be seen, the field of stereoisomer-differentiated recognition and activation of ADRBs is only beginning to be explored.

    Putting Together the Puzzle: Implications for Medicinal Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In the unmedicated organism, endogenous catecholamines (noradrenaline or adrenaline) reach ADRB1 and ADRB2 adrenoceptors. The current contribution poses that the ability of these monoarylethylamine compounds to reach their well-known orthosteric binding site on adrenoceptors is strongly influenced by conformational states of the receptor that are stabilized as a ligand approaches ADRB1s and ADRB2s.(1, 89-91, 116, 162-169) However, although there could be different conformations of the receptor as a population at any one time to which ligands can stabilize and therefore signal (or block signaling) down, it is possible that one ground state conformation has more prevalence over other possible states.
    There is abundant evidence that a secondary binding region does indeed exist near the orthosteric site and that it influences adrenoceptor activity. It is still unclear whether the exposure of such a second binding region is constant or depends on concerted conformational changes. The latter possibility has been suggested for ADRB1s, ADRB2s, and other 7TMRs.(170-173)
    On the basis of growing evidence (provided by in vitro and in silico data) of multiple conformational states and two distinctive regions into the binding site, we propose that a secondary binding region in some cases not only influences allosteric/orthosteric binding but also participates in the activation of the receptor through both the adenylyl cyclase and the β-arrestin pathways, exerting a greater effect on the latter. Our proposal locates this secondary binding region close to but shallower than the orthosteric site, probably in the same crevice or pocket as the orthosteric binding site in some conformational states (as has been found for some biarylamine ADRB1 and/or ADRB2 ligands; Figure 6).
    It seems that several conformational changes can occur in a secondary region or the orthosteric binding site as a result of the approach of a ligand (monoarylethylamine) to any of both sites on the receptor. Recently developed biarylethylamine compounds have been shown to be “superagonists” for ADRBs, apparently concertedly binding to the orthosteric site and a secondary region and thus modifying the β-arrestin signaling pathway.(168) Observed patterns in ligand recognition suggest that certain moieties tend to recognize the secondary binding region while others are prone to recognizing the orthosteric binding site. In the same sense, a single bitopic ligand (or two small ligands acting almost simultaneously) could concertedly bind to both sites with two structurally related moieties (i.e., a homobivalent compound) on ADRB2s.(32, 174)
    Furthermore, we propose that the effect of ligands mediated by contacts with the shallower secondary binding region is due to stabilization of specific ADRB conformations that alter the signaling pathways (Figure 7). Extracellular loops seem to exert an important influence on the capacity of ligands to bind to the allosteric region or orthosteric site.(32) In addition to affinity, the conformation stabilized by interactions in the secondary region could also affect the efficacy of ligands,(174-177) the duration of ligand–receptor binding and receptor signaling, and the selectivity and stereoselectivity of adrenoceptors. The study of the possible existence of other secondary regions in the extracellular loops of ADRBs might facilitate the design and synthesis of drugs with longer action and greater selectivity for ADRB1s and ADRB2s.
    During the preparation of this manuscript, new reports on structure-based drug design for ADRBs (Figure 3)(178-180) provide evidence that is in agreement with the proposal herein outlined. The study by Mistry et al.(179) shows the design of structures in which specific moieties (extended alkoxyalkoxy side chain alongside substituents at the meta or para position of the phenylurea) increase ligand affinity and the selectivity of partial agonists on ADRB1. Weiss et al.(180) found that conformations of ADRB2 are important for the design of ligands with specific efficacy on the G protein and arrestin mediated signaling. Moreover, they showed that some moieties, including those found in 12, are related to arrestin biased signaling. Finally, Christopher et al.(178) showed that the use of biophysical fragment screening to identify high affinity and ligand efficient fragments can yield optimum ligands that can be crystallized on these receptors. It is hoped that these and other studies will eventually generate new strategies for the development of drugs that can serve as therapies for cardiovascular, pulmonary, and metabolic disorders.
    Author Contributions

    M.A.S.-U. performed the database literature search, put forward the ideas, and wrote the initial version of this manuscript. J.G.T.-F. enriched it with application of organic chemistry and stereochemistry topics. J.C.-B. improved it with applications and advances in bioinformatics applied to adrenoceptors studies. S.V. detailed the entire manuscript and enriched it with pharmacology of 7TM receptors and bioinformatics terms used through this perspective. All authors revised it to the final version of this manuscript.

    seven-transmembrane domain receptor

    AR

    adrenoceptor

    ADRB1

    β1 adrenoceptor

    ADRB2

    β2 adrenoceptor

    extracellular loop

    transmembrane domain

    extracellular regulated kinase

    References

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    This article references 180 other publications.

    1. 1
      Kobilka, B. K. Structural insights into adrenergic receptor function and pharmacology Trends Pharmacol. Sci. 2011, 32, 213– 218
      Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    2. 2
      Congreve, M.; Marshall, F. The impact of GPCR structures on pharmacology and structure-based drug design Br. J. Pharmacol. 2010, 159, 986– 996
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      The impact of GPCR structures on pharmacology and structure-based drug design
      Congreve, Miles; Marshall, Fiona
      British Journal of Pharmacology (2010), 159 (5), 986-996CODEN: BJPCBM; ISSN:1476-5381. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A review. After many years of effort, recent tech. breakthroughs have enabled the X-ray crystal structures of three G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) (β1 and β2 adrenergic and adenosine A2a) to be solved in addn. to rhodopsin. GPCRs, like other membrane proteins, have lagged behind sol. drug targets such as kinases and proteases in the no. of structures available and the level of understanding of these targets and their interaction with drugs. The availability of increasing nos. of structures of GPCRs is set to greatly increase our understanding of some of the key issues in GPCR biol. In particular, what constitutes the different receptor conformations that are involved in signaling and the mol. changes which occur upon receptor activation. How future GPCR structures might alter our views on areas such as agonist-directed signaling and allosteric regulation as well as dimerization is discussed. Knowledge of crystal structures in complex with small mols. will enable techniques in drug discovery and design, which have previously only been applied to sol. targets, to now be used for GPCR targets. These methods include structure-based drug design, virtual screening and fragment screening. This review considers how these methods have been used to address problems in drug discovery for kinase and protease targets and therefore how such methods are likely to impact GPCR drug discovery in the future.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXjs1ektro%253D&md5=e9ab946b907eb44edf516eb3231e6931
    3. 3
      Taira, C. A.; Carranza, A.; Mayer, M.; Di Verniero, C.; Opezzo, A.; Höcht, C. Therapeutic implication of beta-adrenergic receptor pharmacodynamic properties Curr. Clin. Pharm. 2008, 3, 174– 184
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Therapeutic implications of beta-adrenergic receptor pharmacodynamic properties
      Taira, Carlos A.; Carranza, Andrea; Mayer, Marcos; Di Verniero, Carla; Opezzo, Javier A. W.; Hocht, Christian
      Current Clinical Pharmacology (2008), 3 (3), 174-184CODEN: CCPUC5; ISSN:1574-8847. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. In the last decades new pharmacodynamic properties of β-adrenoceptors have been discovered that could greatly impact in the use of β-adrenergic agents in the clin. practice. Concepts such as multiple binding sites, constitutive activity, polymorphism and intracellular signaling of β-adrenoceptors may contribute in the discovery of more efficacious pharmacol. agents for treatment of heart failure and asthma. β-Adrenoceptors show a relative high constitutive activity in both cardiac and pulmonary tissues. Most β-blockers exert an inverse agonist action that could contribute to their beneficial effects in the treatment of heart failure. Recently, the existence of multiple affinity sites has been described for β1-adrenoceptor. It was proposed that β-blockers that show agonist properties at the β1L-adrenoceptors binding site may exert neutral or harmful effects when used for treatment of heart failure. Considering the cardiac effect of β1L-adrenoceptors, activation of the low-affinity state of β1-adrenoceptor could be deleterious in cardiovascular pharmacol. The ability of β2-adrenoceptor to couple to Gs or Gi-protein gives the possibility that different agonists can activate different signaling cascades. Full β2-adrenoceptor agonists would be highly useful for improvement bronchodilatation in the acute treatment of asthma. Polymorphic variants of β-adrenoceptors have profound impact in the understanding of normal physiol. and pathophysiol. Genotypic characterization of patients could improve selection of patients during β-adrenergic pharmacotherapies. The aim of the present review is to describe new insights in pharmacol. and biochem. properties of β-adrenoceptors and their impact on the use of β-adrenergic agents in the treatment of cardiovascular and respiratory diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXitF2hsbs%253D&md5=d397d834d6789327467c8f9500a7d0b6
    4. 4
      Limbird, L. E. Historical perspective for understanding of adrenergic receptors Curr. Top. Membr. 2011, 67, 1– 17
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Historical perspective for understanding of adrenergic receptors
      Limbird, Lee E.
      Current Topics in Membranes (2011), 67 (Advances in Adrenergic Receptor Biology), 1-17CODEN: CTMEET; ISSN:1063-5823. (Elsevier Inc.)
      A review focuses primarily on the evolution of understanding of β-, and to a lesser extent α2-,adrenergic receptors. It discusses the difference between agonist and antagonist; use of rhodopsin in study of adrenergic receptor structure-function studies; arrestins; mol. cloning permits structure-function anal. of adrenergic receptors via multiple exptl. strategies; gene targeting studies reveal subtype selective roles for adrenergic receptors in in vivo settings; multiple interacting proteins of adrenergic receptors; specificity and therapeutic selectivity.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtVynt73K&md5=5fe5b763ae95b944304972ec3dc682fe

      Dixon, R. A.; Kobilka, B. K.; Strader, D. J.; Benovic, J. L.; Dohlman, H. G.; Frielle, T.; Bolanowski, M. A.; Bennett, C. D.; Rands, E.; Diehl, R. E.; Mumford, R. A.; Slater, E. E.; Sigal, I. S.; Caron, M. G.; Lefkowitz, R. J.; Strader, C. D. Cloning of the gene and cDNA for mammalian beta-adrenergic receptor and homology with rhodopsin Nature 1986, 321, 75– 79

      Palczewski, K.; Kumasaka, T.; Hori, T.; Behnke, C. A.; Motoshima, H.; Fox, B. A.; Trong, I. L.; Teller, D. C.; Okada, T.; Stenkamp, R. E.; Yamamoto, M.; Miyano, M. Crystal structure of rhodopsin: a G protein-coupled receptor Science 2000, 289, 739– 745
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Crystal structure of rhodopsin: A G protein-coupled receptor
      Palczewski, Krzysztof; Kumasaka, Takashi; Hori, Tetsuya; Behnke, Craig A.; Motoshima, Hiroyuki; Fox, Brian A.; Le Trong, Isolde; Teller, David C.; Okada, Tetsuji; Stenkamp, Ronald E.; Yamamoto, Masaki; Miyano, Masashi
      Science (Washington, D. C.) (2000), 289 (5480), 739-745CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Heterotrimeric guanine nucleotide-binding protein (G protein)-coupled receptors (GPCRs) respond to a variety of different external stimuli and activate G proteins. GPCRs share many structural features, including a bundle of seven transmembrane α-helixes connected by six loops of varying lengths. We detd. the structure of rhodopsin from diffraction data extending to 2.8 angstroms resoln. The highly organized structure in the extracellular region, including a conserved disulfide bridge, forms a basis for the arrangement of the seven-helix transmembrane motif. The ground-state chromophore, 11-cis-retinal, holds the transmembrane region of the protein in the inactive conformation. Interactions of the chromophore with a cluster of key residues det. the wavelength of the max. absorption. Changes in these interactions among rhodopsins facilitate color discrimination. Identification of a set of residues that mediate interactions between the transmembrane helixes and the cytoplasmic surface, where G-protein activation occurs, also suggests a possible structural change upon photoactivation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXlslOqs78%253D&md5=b3d229fc696247ec0f4a6efa10490922
    7. 7
      Rasmussen, S. G.; Choi, H. J.; Rosenbaum, D. M.; Kobilka, T. S.; Thian, F. S.; Edwards, P. C.; Burghammer, M.; Ratnala, V. R.; Sanishvili, R.; Fischetti, R. F.; Schertler, G. F.; Weis, W. I.; Kobilka, B. K. Crystal structure of the human β2 adrenergic G-protein-coupled receptor Nature 2007, 450, 383– 387
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Crystal structure of the human β2 adrenergic G-protein-coupled receptor
      Rasmussen, Soren G. F.; Choi, Hee-Jung; Rosenbaum, Daniel M.; Kobilka, Tong Sun; Thian, Foon Sun; Edwards, Patricia C.; Burghammer, Manfred; Ratnala, Venkata R. P.; Sanishvili, Ruslan; Fischetti, Robert F.; Schertler, Gebhard F. X.; Weis, William I.; Kobilka, Brian K.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2007), 450 (7168), 383-387CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Structural anal. of G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) for hormones and neurotransmitters has been hindered by their low natural abundance, inherent structural flexibility, and instability in detergent solns. Here we report a structure of the human β2 adrenoceptor (β2AR), which was crystd. in a lipid environment when bound to an inverse agonist and in complex with a Fab that binds to the third intracellular loop. Diffraction data were obtained by high-brilliance microcrystallog. and the structure detd. at 3.4 Å/3.7 Å resoln. The cytoplasmic ends of the β2AR transmembrane segments and the connecting loops are well resolved, whereas the extracellular regions of the β2AR are not seen. The β2AR structure differs from rhodopsin in having weaker interactions between the cytoplasmic ends of transmembrane (TM)3 and TM6, involving the conserved E/DRY sequences. These differences may be responsible for the relatively high basal activity and structural instability of the β2AR, and contribute to the challenges in obtaining diffraction-quality crystals of non-rhodopsin GPCRs.

      High-Resolution Crystal Structure of an Engineered Human β2-Adrenergic G Protein-Coupled Receptor
      Cherezov, Vadim; Rosenbaum, Daniel M.; Hanson, Michael A.; Rasmussen, Soren G. F.; Thian, Foon Sun; Kobilka, Tong Sun; Choi, Hee-Jung; Kuhn, Peter; Weis, William I.; Kobilka, Brian K.; Stevens, Raymond C.; Takeda, S.; Kadowaki, S.; Haga, T.; Takaesu, H.; Mitaku, S.; Fredriksson, R.; Lagerstrom, M. C.; Lundin, L. G.; Schioth, H. B.; Pierce, K. L.; Premont, R. T.; Lefkowitz, R. J.; Lefkowitz, R. J.; Shenoy, S. K.; Rosenbaum, D. M.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2007), 318 (5854), 1258-1265CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Second extracellular loop, which in the β2-adrenergic receptor contains an unusual pair of disulfide bonds and an extra helix. This loop and the absence Heterotrimeric guanine nucleotide-binding protein (G protein)-coupled receptors constitute the largest family of eukaryotic signal transduction proteins that communicate across the membrane. We report the crystal structure of a human β2-adrenergic receptor-T4 lysozyme fusion protein bound to the partial inverse agonist carazolol at 2.4 angstrom resoln. The structure provides a high-resoln. view of a human G protein-coupled receptor bound to a diffusible ligand. Ligand-binding site accessibility is enabled by the second extracellular loop, which is held out of the binding cavity by a pair of closely spaced disulfide bridges and a short helical segment within the loop. Cholesterol, a necessary component for crystn., mediates an intriguing parallel assocn. of receptor mols. in the crystal lattice. Although the location of carazolol in the β2-adrenergic receptor is very similar to that of retinal in rhodopsin, structural differences in the ligand-binding site and other regions highlight the challenges in using rhodopsin as a template model for this large receptor family.

      10
      Conserved Binding Mode of Human β2 Adrenergic Receptor Inverse Agonists and Antagonist Revealed by X-ray Crystallography
      Wacker, Daniel; Fenalti, Gustavo; Brown, Monica A.; Katritch, Vsevolod; Abagyan, Ruben; Cherezov, Vadim; Stevens, Raymond C.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (33), 11443-11445CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) represent a large fraction of current pharmaceutical targets, and of the GPCRs, the β2 adrenergic receptor (β2AR) is one of the most extensively studied. Previously, the x-ray crystal structure of β2AR has been detd. in complex with two partial inverse agonists, but the global impact of addnl. ligands on the structure or local impacts on the binding site are not well-understood. To assess the extent of such ligand-induced conformational differences, we detd. the crystal structures of a previously described engineered β2AR construct in complex with two inverse agonists: ICI 118,551 (2.8 Å), a recently described compd. (2.8 Å) (Kolb et al, 2009), and the antagonist alprenolol (3.1 Å). The structures show the same overall fold obsd. for the previous β2AR structures and demonstrate that the ligand binding site can accommodate compds. of different chem. and pharmacol. properties with only minor local structural rearrangements. All three compds. contain a hydroxy-amine motif that establishes a conserved hydrogen bond network with the receptor and chem. diverse arom. moieties that form distinct interactions with β2AR. Furthermore, receptor ligand cross-docking expts. revealed that a single β2AR complex can be suitable for docking of a range of antagonists and inverse agonists but also indicate that addnl. ligand-receptor structures may be useful to further improve performance for in-silico docking or lead-optimization in drug design.

      Structure of the Human Dopamine D3 Receptor in Complex with a D2/D3 Selective Antagonist
      Chien, Ellen Y. T.; Liu, Wei; Zhao, Qiang; Katritch, Vsevolod; Won Han, Gye; Hanson, Michael A.; Shi, Lei; Newman, Amy Hauck; Javitch, Jonathan A.; Cherezov, Vadim; Stevens, Raymond C.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 330 (6007), 1091-1095CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Dopamine modulates movement, cognition, and emotion through activation of dopamine G protein-coupled receptors in the brain. The crystal structure of the human dopamine D3 receptor (D3R) in complex with the small mol. D2R/D3R-specific antagonist eticlopride reveals important features of the ligand binding pocket and extracellular loops. On the intracellular side of the receptor, a locked conformation of the ionic lock and two distinctly different conformations of intracellular loop 2 are obsd. Docking of R-22, a D3R-selective antagonist, reveals an extracellular extension of the eticlopride binding site that comprises a second binding pocket for the aryl amide of R-22, which differs between the highly homologous D2R and D3R. This difference provides direction to the design of D3R-selective agents for treating drug abuse and other neuropsychiatric indications.

      13
      Structure of a nanobody-stabilized active state of the β2 adrenoceptor
      Rasmussen, Soren G. F.; Choi, Hee-Jung; Fung, Juan Jose; Pardon, Els; Casarosa, Paola; Chae, Pil Seok; DeVree, Brian T.; Rosenbaum, Daniel M.; Thian, Foon Sun; Kobilka, Tong Sun; Schnapp, Andreas; Konetzki, Ingo; Sunahara, Roger K.; Gellman, Samuel H.; Pautsch, Alexander; Steyaert, Jan; Weis, William I.; Kobilka, Brian K.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2011), 469 (7329), 175-180CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      G protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) exhibit a spectrum of functional behaviors in response to natural and synthetic ligands. Recent crystal structures provide insights into inactive states of several GPCRs. Efforts to obtain an agonist-bound active-state GPCR structure have proven difficult due to the inherent instability of this state in the absence of a G protein. We generated a camelid antibody fragment (nanobody) to the human β2 adrenergic receptor (β2AR) that exhibits G protein-like behavior, and obtained an agonist-bound, active-state crystal structure of the receptor-nanobody complex. Comparison with the inactive β2AR structure reveals subtle changes in the binding pocket; however, these small changes are assocd. with an 11 Å outward movement of the cytoplasmic end of transmembrane segment 6, and rearrangements of transmembrane segments 5 and 7 that are remarkably similar to those obsd. in opsin, an active form of rhodopsin. This structure provides insights into the process of agonist binding and activation.

      Stevens, R. C.; Cherezov, V.; Katritch, V.; Abagyan, R.; Kuhn, P.; Rosen, H.; Wüthrich, K. The GPCR network: a large-scale collaboration to determine human GPCR structure and function Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2013, 12, 25– 34

      19
      The GPCR Network: a large-scale collaboration to determine human GPCR structure and function
      Stevens, Raymond C.; Cherezov, Vadim; Katritch, Vsevolod; Abagyan, Ruben; Kuhn, Peter; Rosen, Hugh; Wuethrich, Kurt
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2013), 12 (1), 25-34CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are targeted by ∼30-40% of marketed drugs, and their key roles in normal physiol. and in disease demonstrate that an understanding of their structure and function is valuable to researchers in both basic science and drug discovery. However, until recently, detailed structural information on this protein family was limited by challenges in X-ray crystallog. anal. of such membrane proteins. The GPCR Network was created in 2010 with the goal of structurally characterizing 15-25 representative human GPCRs within 5 years, based on an active outreach program addressing an interdisciplinary community of scientists interested in GPCR structure, chem. and biol. Here, we provide an overview of how this collaborative effort has enabled the structural detn. and characterization of eight human GPCRs so far, and discuss some of the challenges that remain in gaining more detailed insights into structure-function relationships in this receptor superfamily.

      Google Scholar

    21. 21
      Jacobson, K. A.; Costanzi, S. New insights for drug design from the X-ray crystallographic structures of G-protein-coupled receptors Mol. Pharmacol. 2012, 82, 361– 371
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      21
      New insights for drug design from the X-ray crystallographic structures of G-protein-coupled receptors
      Jacobson, Kenneth A.; Costanzi, Stefano
      Molecular Pharmacology (2012), 82 (3), 361-371CODEN: MOPMA3; ISSN:1521-0111. (American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics)
      A review. Methodol. advances in x-ray crystallog. have made possible the recent soln. of x-ray structures of pharmaceutically important G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), including receptors for biogenic amines, peptides, a nucleoside, and a sphingolipid. These high-resoln. structures have greatly increased our understanding of ligand recognition and receptor activation. Conformational changes assocd. with activation common to several receptors entail outward movements of the intracellular side of transmembrane helix 6 (TM6) and movements of TM5 toward TM6. Movements assocd. with specific agonists or receptors were also described [e.g., extracellular loop (EL) 3 in the A2A adenosine receptor]. The binding sites of different receptors partly overlap but differ significantly in ligand orientation, depth, and breadth of contact areas in TM regions and the involvement of the ELs. A current challenge is how to use this structural information for the rational design of novel potent and selective ligands. For example, new chemotypes were discovered as antagonists of various GPCRs by subjecting chem. libraries to in silico docking in the x-ray structures. The vast majority of GPCR structures and their ligand complexes are still unsolved, and no structures are known outside of family A GPCRs. Mol. modeling, informed by supporting information from site-directed mutagenesis and structure-activity relationships, was validated as a useful tool to extend structural insights to related GPCRs and to analyze docking of other ligands in already crystd. GPCRs.

      Wang, C.; Wu, H.; Katritch, V.; Han, G. W.; Huang, X. P.; Liu, W.; Siu, F. Y.; Roth, B. L.; Cherezov, V.; Stevens, R. C. Structure of the human smoothened receptor bound to an antitumour agent Nature 2013, 497, 338– 343
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      25
      Structure of the human smoothened receptor bound to an antitumour agent
      Wang, Chong; Wu, Huixian; Katritch, Vsevolod; Han, Gye Won; Huang, Xi-Ping; Liu, Wei; Siu, Fai Yiu; Roth, Bryan L.; Cherezov, Vadim; Stevens, Raymond C.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2013), 497 (7449), 338-343CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      The smoothened (SMO) receptor, a key signal transducer in the hedgehog signalling pathway, is responsible for the maintenance of normal embryonic development and is implicated in carcinogenesis. It is classified as a class frizzled (class F) G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), although the canonical hedgehog signalling pathway involves the GLI transcription factors and the sequence similarity with class A GPCRs is less than 10%. Here we report the crystal structure of the transmembrane domain of the human SMO receptor bound to the small-mol. antagonist LY2940680 at 2.5 Å resoln. Although the SMO receptor shares the seven-transmembrane helical (7TM) fold, most of the conserved motifs for class A GPCRs are absent, and the structure reveals an unusually complex arrangement of long extracellular loops stabilized by four disulfide bonds. The ligand binds at the extracellular end of the seven-transmembrane-helix bundle and forms extensive contacts with the loops.
